metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Respondent (Employee of Dadajee Dhackjee & Co.)

facts.text: Respondent was an employee of Dadajee Dhackjee & Co., Bombay (the firm). The firm paid each of its three employees, including respondent, commission of one per cent on total annual turnover of Colour Department in addition to salaries.

For assessment year 1945-46 (accounting year Sambat 2000: October 30, 1943 to October 17, 1944), ITO found profit and loss account of Colour Department debited with Rs. 84,540 as commission to three employees (3% on turnover, 1% each).

In preceding year (Sambat 1999, assessment 1944-45), ITO allowed only 1% commission as reasonable deduction u/s 10(2)(xv), disallowed balance of 2%. Same applied to 1945-46: allowed Rs. 28,180 (1%), disallowed Rs. 56,360.
Share of each employee in disallowed amount for Sambat 2000: Rs. 18,787.

Profit of Colour Department raised from Rs. 4,27,139 to Rs. 5,30,900 by adding back Rs. 56,360 commission disallowance and other sums. Reason: 2/3 commission unreasonable and excessive, not permissible u/s 10(2)(xv).
After deducting Rs. 1,19,816 loss of Motor Department, firm's total income computed at Rs. 4,11,084.
Firm registered u/s 26A, no demand on firm u/s 23(5)(a), income distributed to two partners (husband and wife). Wife's share included in husband's u/s 16(3)(i).
Firm claimed and granted relief u/s 25(4) as business taken over by Dadajee Dhackjee & Co. Ltd. from Sambat 2001, notice given June 4, 1945.

Respondent submitted returns on March 19, 1949 for 1944-45 to 1948-49. Claimed exemption from tax on disallowed commission (Rs. 18,787 for 1945-46) per Notification No. 878-F dated March 21, 1922 (as amended).
ITO rejected claim, upheld by AAC and Tribunal. Tribunal: Notification inapplicable as firm's income not assessed/charged to tax.
Tribunal referred question u/s 66(1) to Bombay High Court on January 14, 1955.
High Court answered question in affirmative (for assessee) on September 22, 1955.
Commissioner obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court u/Article 136.

legal_issues.text: Whether the assessee is entitled to relief granted by Notification No. 878-F dated March 21, 1922 (as amended)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Commission not paid out of profits, as P&L shows profit of Rs. 4,27,139 after deducting commission; profit ascertained after outgoings.
Disallowance not because paid/determined with reference to profits, but because excessive/unreasonable u/s 10(2)(xv).
No income-tax assessed and charged on firm's income under head 'business'; no demand due to s.26A, s.23(5)(a), relief u/s 25(4); distinction between assessable income and actual profit.

respondent_arguments.text: Commission paid out of real profits (Rs. 5,30,900 before disallowance/add-backs).
Income computed/assessable, thus statutorily charged to tax u/s 3.

court_reasoning.text: Notification requires three cumulative conditions: (1) sum paid out of/determined ref. profits; (2) not allowed as deduction by reason of such mode but included in profits; (3) income-tax assessed and charged under head 'business' on such sum.
Assumes (without deciding) first condition satisfied (commission paid out of profits).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not necessary to decide as point not raised earlier.

court_reasoning.text: Assumes second condition, though disallowance due to excessiveness, not mode of payment (point not raised earlier).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot base decision on unraised ground.

court_reasoning.text: 'Charged' means actual levy, not mere statutory liability u/s 3. No assessment/charge/levy on firm due to s.26A relief and s.25(4); ITO need not have assessed at all.

holdings.text: Referred question answered in the negative; assessee not entitled to relief under Notification.

precedents_cited.relevance: Referred to certain High Court and Privy Council decisions on distinction between actual profit and assessable income, but not specified or decided upon.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs deductions for commission, firm registration, no demand on registered firm, inclusion of wife's share, relief on succession, charging section, reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Notification No. 878-F dated March 21, 1922 (as amended by No. 8 dated March 24, 1928)
statutes_cited.relevance: Exempts sums like commission paid out of profits, disallowed but included in business profits on which tax assessed/charged.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, answered the referred question in the negative, holding assessee not entitled to exemption under the Notification as third condition not satisfied (no actual tax charged on firm's income).

key_quotes.text: The obvious purpose of this notification is to avoid double taxation by providing that if the amount in question has been assessed and charged in the hands of the firm, the same should not be assessed and charged over again in the hands of the assessee.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose and interpretation of Notification.

key_quotes.text: These three conditions are cumulative and all of them have to be fulfilled before the assessee can claim the benefit of exemption.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines requirements for relief under Notification.

key_quotes.text: The word 'charged' does not, in the Notification, mean the mere statutory liability to pay tax but goes further and includes the actual charge or levy.
key_quotes.speaker: court
